awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Totten Glacier System and the Marine Record of  Cryosphere - Ocean Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the marine component of the Totten Glacier and Moscow University Ice Shelf, East Antarctica. This system is of critical importance because it drains one-eighth of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet and contains a volume equivalent to nearly 7 meters of potential sea level rise, greater than the entire West Antarctic Ice Sheet. This nearly completely unexplored region is the single largest and least understood marine glacial system that is potentially unstable. Despite intense scrutiny of marine based systems in the West Antarctic Ice Sheet, little is known about the Totten Glacier system. This study will add substantially to the meager oceanographic and marine geology and geophysics data available in this region, and will significantly advance understanding of this poorly understood glacial system and its potentially sensitive response to environmental change.

Independent, space-based platforms indicate accelerating mass loss of the Totten system. Recent aerogeophysical surveys of the Aurora Subglacial Basin, which contains the deepest ice in Antarctica and drains into the Totten system, have provided the subglacial context for measured surface changes and show that the Totten Glacier has been the most significant drainage pathway for at least two previous ice flow regimes. However, the offshore context is far less understood. Limited physical oceanographic data from the nearby shelf/slope break indicate the presence of Modified Circumpolar Deep Water within a thick bottom layer at the mouth of a trough with apparent access to Totten Glacier, suggesting the possibility of sub-glacial bottom inflow of relatively warm water, a process considered to be responsible for West Antarctic Ice Sheet grounding line retreat. This project will conduct a ship-based marine geologic and geophysical survey of the region, combined with a physical oceanographic study, in order to evaluate both the recent and longer-term behavior of the glacial system and its relationship to the adjacent oceanographic system.  This endeavor will complement studies of other Antarctic ice shelves, oceanographic studies near the Antarctic Peninsula, and ongoing development of ice sheet and other ocean models.

por.por_cntn:
Today’s world is characterized by complex changes that are driven by a warming atmosphere.  Of primary concern is the potential for runaway ice loss and sea level rise, with attention focused on regions where the Antarctic Ice Sheet is grounded below sea level. The Sabrina Coast, East Antarctica, is an area of interest because (1) satellite and airborne geophysical studies indicate substantial loss of glacial ice over the past decade, and (2) the region is underlain by the deep Aurora Subglacial Basin, a configuration that is susceptible to instability. This project focused on study of the coastal ocean region offshore of the Sabrina Coast. This area is adjacent to the Totten Glacier, which is the termination of the largest marine-based portion of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet. Prior to this project, little was known about the factors influencing the present and past behavior of ice in this region, due its remote location and the heavy sea ice cover that restricts most ship-based access. A 2014 research cruise aboard the RVIB NB Palmer (NBP1402) conducted a comprehensive survey of this region.

 

Main accomplishments include:

 

1. First bathymetric map of the continental shelf close to the Totten Glacier system. These new seafloor maps document the history of thicker grounded ice in the past, and also the presence of deep troughs that could serve as pathways for the transport of oceanic heat to the ice margin. Geomorphic features at the seafloor, such as glacial lineations, ridges, and moraines, trace past ice flow direction and changes in the rate of ice retreat over time.

 

2. Physical oceanographic data were collected, both during the cruise, and over the course of the following year, via instruments temporarily left in the water and collected when the region was re-visited a year later. These data include information about the temperature and salinity characteristics of the ocean, and document the presence of warm ocean waters over the continental shelf. The role of this relatively warm water in driving ice loss continues to be studied.

 

3. The first marine geophysical seismic survey of the continental shelf, combined with strategic coring of sediments, documents the long-term evolution of the Aurora Subglacial Basin. These data show that ancient river systems once occupied a much warmer East Antarctica, with development of a dynamic glacial system over the past several tens of millions of years.

 

4. Sediment cores were collected that reach back to the Last Glacial Maximum, when glacial ice of the East Antarctic ice sheet was more extensive and grounded on the Sabrina Coast continental shelf. Several kinds of analyses were completed on these cores including work on the sedimentology, geochemistry, and microfossil content. These data paint of picture of the timing and nature of ice retreat in this region. The warmest and most productive time since grounded glacial ice retreated about 15,000 years ago, was from about 11,000-5000 years ago. Since then, the region appears to have cooled.   

 

5. Using bottom cameras that took still images and captured video, we conducted the first analysis of benthic organisms and habitats from the Sabrina Coast shelf, a region encompassing a proposed Marine Protected Area.

 

6. Based on analysis of the chemistry and species composition of living surface water plankton, we provided ground-truth data for a biogeochemical marker or fingerprint that can be used to trace the past presence of sea ice. This will help scientists understand how and why the extent of sea ice varies over time.

 

Broader impacts of this project include the shipboard and shore-based training of undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students. In addition, we were joined on our cruise by a wilderness studies and biology teacher from Upstate New York, as part of the PolarTrec Teacher program. Our teacher developed hands-on educational activities, spoke at many upstate New York K-12 schools, and conducted radio interviews for North Country Public Radio. This project also facilitated international collaboration with Australian research colleagues, through joint shipboard participation, and through the cooperative deployment and recovery of moored instrumentation that recorded data in place, for a year. The data collected for this project will improve the ability of climate modelers to evaluate the response of the East Antarctic Ice Sheet and nearby ocean to future warming, and our abilities to reconstruct past glacial and sea ice. Finally, modern data concerning sea floor organisms will provide a baseline for assessing the impacts of future natural and man-made change on seafloor organisms and sea bed habitats of the Sabrina Coast continental shelf.
